
The definition statements of the previous chapter are used to define the components of the system
and the relationships between the various components. Before the system can be analyzed, however, it
is necessary to supply the numeric data appropriate to each of the entities defined. This is the
purpose of the &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements presented in this chapter.

Each of the &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements begins with the keyword &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; followed by a separator. The second
word of each &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statement is also treated as a keyword, instructing the IMP system to interpret
the remainder of the statement according to one of the following formats:


==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch4_1.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 4-1:'']]
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the numeric data which locate one of the coordinate systems
attached to one of the links relative to the absolute (global) frame of reference for the system.

The &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements, taken together with the &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements for the various joint types
(&lt;tt&gt;DATA SPHERE&lt;/tt&gt; statements, etc.), describe the relative locations of the various links and joints
of the system at the initial (design) position.

The initial location of one local coordinate system, attached to one of the links is defined by each
&lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement by specifying the global coordinates of three points (see figure). The first
point must lie at the origin of the local coordinate system; the second point must be chosen on the
local positive ''w'' or ''z'' axis; the third point should lie on the positive ''u'' or ''x'' axis
of the local ''u'',''v'',''w'' coordinate system attached to the joint element or the local
''x'',''y'',''z'' coordinate system attached to the link.

===Format===
There are two forms of the &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement.

The first form is used to specify the location of one local coordinate system attached to an element
of a joint. The format is

 DATA LINK(link name,joint name) = x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;

where ''link name'' and ''joint name'' are the alphanumeric names of the link and joint to which
this local coordinate system is attached. The ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups are numeric
values for the global coordinates of the three points defining the initial location of a local
(''u'',''v'',''w'') joint element coordinate system.

The second form is identical to the first except the ''joint name'' is replaced by the keyword
&lt;tt&gt;LINK&lt;/tt&gt;. This format is:

 DATA LINK (link name, LINK) = x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;

which indicates that the primary local coordinate system for the ''link name'' is being located.

===Examples===
 DATA LINK (BAR,PIN) = -1.0,2.5,0.0; -1.0,3.5,0.0; -2.0,2.5,1.0

specifies the location of a joint named ''PIN'' at one end of a link named ''BAR''. The numeric data
corresponds approximately to the figure.

The above example might also take any of the following forms:

 DATA LINK (BAR, PIN) = -1,2.5,0; -1,3.5,0; -2,2.5,1
 DATA LINK (BAR, PIN) = -1,2.5, ; -1,3.5, ; -2,2.5,1
 DATA LINK (BAR, PIN) = PT1; PT2; -2,2.5,1

===Notes===
# When a ''link name'' is first defined in the system model (whether by a &lt;tt&gt;LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement or by a joint definition statement) a local coordinate system for the link is formed in the system memory. This link coordinate system is initially located coincident with the global coordinate system, but may be moved to another location by the &lt;tt&gt;LINK&lt;/tt&gt; form of the &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# When a ''joint name'' is first defined by a joint definition statement, two local joint coordinate systems are formed in the system memory, one attached to each of the two ''link names'' joined by the joint. These are initially placed coincident with the local coordinate systems of the two ''link names'', but each may be moved to some other location on the link by the ''joint name'' form of the &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# If the ''joint name'' form is used, both ''link name'' and ''joint name'' must have been used in the same previous statement defining that joint. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# When the ''joint name'' form is used, global coordinate data are given by the user for the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups. However, this is converted in memory to a (''u'',''v'',''w'') or (&lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt;) location for that ''joint name'' element with respect to the specified ''link name''. This data is then considered fixed; if the link is moved, the joint elements move in unison with it.
# When the &lt;tt&gt;LINK&lt;/tt&gt; form is used, the local coordinate system of the link is moved to another location as specified by the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' data. Any data referenced to the link coordinate system (such as the locations of local joint coordinate systems, any points attached to the link, any geometric shape data from a &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement, etc.) all move if the local link coordinate system is moved by the &lt;tt&gt;LINK&lt;/tt&gt; form of a &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''link name'', the later statement takes precedence and earlier data are replaced. No message is printed.
# Notice that notes 1) through 6) above make the order in which related &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements are given very important; related &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements might not produce the same result if given in different orders.
# The dimensions for all ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data in a &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement are length units measured in the global coordinate system.
# Care should be taken in supplying accurate dimensional data since any errors result in improper shapes for the links and remain throughout the simulation. Slight errors cause inaccurate answers, while gross errors may cause completely unpredictable results.
# The ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups of numeric data must correspond to the rules for the placement of the local joint coordinate systems (refer to the statement defining each particular type of joint). If errors are detected, the corresponding &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed. Certain types of errors may not be detected until an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given; these cause the simulation to be halted and a message to be printed at that time.
# The three points for which ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are given need not be unit distances apart; the local coordinate axes are normalized by IMP to form unit vectors. The points should not be chosen coincident or too close together, however; larger distances achieve more accurate placement of axes.
# The angle formed by points ''2'',''1'',''3'' need not be a right angle. IMP uses the first point to locate the local origin and uses the second point to define the direction of the local w or z axis; the local ''u'' or ''x'' axis is then taken in the half-plane defined by the local ''w'' or ''z'' axis and the third point. Any necessary adjustments are made to the third point to produce a local coordinate system with exact right angles.
# If the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are not given for the third point, the coordinates of the global origin are used. This may be a convenient shortcut if the user is not concerned about the particular placement of the local u or x axis. In view of notes 11) and 12) above, this does not produce an error unless the local w or z axis passes through the global origin.
# Any of the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups of numeric data may be replaced by the alphanumeric name of a previously defined point for which a valid &lt;tt&gt;DATA POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement has previously been given (see above example).


==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch4_2.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 4-2:'']]
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement simultaneously specifies the numeric data which locate the two local
coordinate systems attached to the two links on either side of a &lt;tt&gt;RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; joint relative to the
absolute (global) frame of reference for the system.

The &lt;tt&gt;DATA RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statements, taken together with the &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements for other types of joints and
the &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements, describe the relative locations of the various links and joints of the
system at the initial (design) position.

The initial locations of the two local coordinate systems attached to the two links joined by a
&lt;tt&gt;RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement are coincident and are both defined by a single &lt;tt&gt;DATA RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement by
specifying the global coordinates of three points (see figure). The first point defines the common
origins of the two local coordinate systems. The second point lies on the common local ''w'' and
&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes and the third point lies on the common local ''u'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes of the coordinate
systems attached to the two links joined.

===Format===
 DATA RIGID (joint name) = x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;

where ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; joint connecting the two links to which
the local coordinate systems are attached. The ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups are numeric
values for the global coordinates of the three points defining the initial locations of the two
local coordinate systems.

===Example===
 DATA RIGID (WELD) = -1.0,2.5,0.0; -1.0,3.5,0.0; -2.0,2.5,1.0

specifies the initial locations of the two coincident local coordinate systems attached to the two
links connected by a &lt;tt&gt;RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; joint named ''WELD''. The above example might also take any of the
following forms:

 DATA RIGID (WELD) = -1,2.5,0; -1,3.5,0; -2,2.5,1
 DATA RIGID (WELD) = -1,2.5, ; -1,3.5, ; -2,2.5,1
 DATA RIGID (WELD) = PT1; PT2; -2,2.5,1
 DATA RIGID (WELD) = PT1; PT2

===Notes===
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# If a &lt;tt&gt;DATA RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement or the two equivalent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements are not specified for each ''joint name'' defined by a &lt;tt&gt;RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'', the later statement takes precedence and earlier data are replaced.
# The dimensions for all ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data in a &lt;tt&gt;DATA RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement are length units.
# Care should be taken in supplying accurate dimensional data since any errors result in improper shapes for the links and remain throughout the simulation. Slight errors cause inaccurate answers, while gross errors may cause completely unpredictable results.
# The ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data must define two coincident local coordinate systems (see &lt;tt&gt;RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# The three points for which ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are given need not be unit distances apart; the local ''u'',''v'',''w'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes are normalized by IMP to form unit vectors. The points should not be chosen coincident or too close together, however; larger distances achieve more accurate placement of axes.
# The angle formed by points ''2'',''1'',''3'' need not be a right angle. IMP uses the first and second point to locate the common local origins and the common local ''w'' and &lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes; the common local ''u'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes are then formed in the half-plane defined by the common local ''w'' and &lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes and the third point. A right angle is formed for the common local ''u'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes in this half-plane even though this direction may not pass through the third point given.
# If the ''x&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;'' data are not given for the third point, the coordinates of the global origin are used. This may be a convenient shortcut if the user is not concerned with the ''u'',&lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axis placement (see final example above). In view of note 8) above, this does not produce an error unless the common local ''w'',&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes pass through the global origin.
# Any of the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups of numeric data may be replaced by the alphanumeric name of a previously defined point for which a valid &lt;tt&gt;DATA POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement has previously been given (see above examples).


==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch4_3.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 4-3:'']]
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the numeric data which simultaneously locate the two local
coordinate systems attached to the two links on either side of an &lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; joint relative to the
absolute (global) frame of reference for the system. The pin axis is initially aligned parallel to
the global X axis.

The &lt;tt&gt;DATA XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statements, taken together with the &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements for other types of joints and
the &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements, describe the relative locations of the various links of the system at
the initial (design) position.

The initial locations of the two local coordinate systems attached to the two links joined by an
&lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement are both defined by a single &lt;tt&gt;DATA XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement by specifying the global
coordinates of three points (see figure). The first point must lie at the common origins of the two
local coordinate systems. The second and third points are optional but, if given, should lie on the
local positive ''v'' and &lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt; axes of the coordinate systems attached to the first and second
links named in the &lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement, respectively.

===Format===
 DATA XPIN (joint name) = x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;

where ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; joint connecting the two links to which
the local ''u'',''v'',''w'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; coordinate systems are attached. The
''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups are numeric values for the global coordinates of the three
points defining the initial locations of the two local coordinate systems.

===Examples===
 DATA XPIN (PIN) = -2.0,2.5,0.0; -2.0,3.5,0.0; -2.0,2.5,1.0

specifies the initial locations of the local coordinate systems attached to the two links on either
side of an &lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; joint named ''PIN''. The numeric data corresponds approximately to the figure. The
above example might also take any of the following forms:

 DATA XPIN (PIN) = -2,2.5,0; -2,3.5,0; -2,2.5,1
 DATA XPIN (PIN) = -2,2.5, ; -2,3.5, ; -2,2.5,1
 DATA XPIN (PIN) = PT1; -2,3.5,0; -2,2.5,1
 DATA XPIN (PIN) = PT1

===Notes===
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# If a &lt;tt&gt;DATA XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement or the two equivalent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements are not specified for each ''joint name'' defined by an &lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'', the later statement takes precedence and earlier data are replaced.
# The dimensions for all ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data in a &lt;tt&gt;DATA XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement are length units.
# Care should be taken in supplying accurate dimensional data since any errors result in improper shapes for the links and remain throughout the simulation. Slight errors cause inaccurate answers, while gross errors may cause completely unpredictable results.
# The ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data must conform to the rules for the placement of the local coordinate systems for an &lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; joint (see &lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement). If errors are detected, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed. Certain types of errors may not be detected until an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given; these cause the simulation to be halted and a message to be printed at that time.
# The three points for which ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are given need not be unit distances apart; the local ''u'',''v'',''w'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes are normalized by IMP to form unit vectors. The points should not be chosen coincident or too close together, however (except, perhaps, for the second and third points); larger distances achieve more accurate placement of axes.
# The angles formed by points ''2'',''1'',''3'' need not lie in a plane perpendicular to the global X axis. IMP uses the first point to locate the common local origins and the common local ''u'',&lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes; the local ''v'' and &lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt; axes are then taken in the half-planes defined by the common local ''u'',&lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes and the second and third points, respectively. Right angles are formed for the local ''v'' and &lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt; axes in these half-planes even though they may not pass precisely through the second and third points, respectively.
# If the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are not given for the second and/or third points, the local coordinate systems are placed parallel to those of the global system. This may be a convenient shortcut (see final example above), if the user is not concerned about the particular placement of the two local ''v'' and/or &lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt; axes.
# Any of the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups of numeric data may be replaced by the alphanumeric name of a previously defined point for which a valid &lt;tt&gt;DATA POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement has previously been given (see above examples).


==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch4_4.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 4-4:'']]
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the numeric data which simultaneously locate the two local
''u'',''v'',''w'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; coordinate systems attached to the two links on either
side of a &lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; joint relative to the absolute (global) frame of reference for the system. The pin
axis is initially aligned parallel to the global Y axis.

The &lt;tt&gt;DATA YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statements, taken together with the &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements for other types of joints and
the &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements, describe the relative locations of the various links of the system at
the initial (design) position.

The initial locations of the two local coordinate systems attached to the two links joined by a
&lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement are both defined by a single &lt;tt&gt;DATA YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement by specifying the global
coordinates of three points (see figure). The first point must lie at the common origins of the two
local ''u'',''v'',''w'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; coordinate systems. The second and third points are
optional but, if given, must lie on the local positive ''w'' and &lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes of the coordinate
systems attached to the first and second links named in the &lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement, respectively.

===Format===
 DATA YPIN (joint name) = x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;

where ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; joint connecting the two links to which
the local ''u'',''v'',''w'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; coordinate systems are attached. The
''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups are numeric values for the global coordinates of the three
points defining the initial locations of the two local coordinate systems.

===Examples===
 DATA YPIN (PIN) = -2.0,2.5,0.0; 0.0,2.5,0.5; -3.0,2.5,1.0

specifies the initial locations of the local coordinate systems attached to the two links on either
side of a &lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; joint named PIN. The numeric data corresponds approximately to the figure. The
above example might also take any of the following forms:

 DATA YPIN (PIN) = -2,2.5,0; 0,2.5,.5; -3,2.5,1
 DATA YPIN (PIN) = -2,2.5, ; ,2.5,.5; -3,2.5,1
 DATA YPIN (PIN) = PT1; ,2.5,.5; -3,2.5,1
 DATA YPIN (PIN) = PT1

===Notes===
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# If a &lt;tt&gt;DATA YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement or the two equivalent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements are not specified for each ''joint name'' defined by a &lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'', the later statement takes precedence and earlier data are replaced.
# The dimensions for all ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data in a &lt;tt&gt;DATA YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement are length units.
# Care should be taken in supplying accurate dimensional data since any errors result in improper shapes for the links and remain throughout the simulation. Slight errors cause inaccurate answers, while gross errors may cause completely unpredictable results.
# The ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data must conform to the rules for the placement of the local coordinate systems for a &lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; joint (see &lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement). If errors are detected, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed. Certain types of errors may not be detected until an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given; these cause the simulation to be halted and a message to be printed at that time.
# The three points for which ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are given need not be unit distances apart; the local ''u'',''v'',''w'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes are normalized by IMP to form unit vectors. The points should not be chosen coincident or too close together, however (except, perhaps, for the second and third points); larger distances achieve more accurate placement of axes.
# The angles formed by points ''2'',''1'',''3'' need not lie in a plane perpendicular to the global Y axis. IMP uses the first point to locate the common local origins and the common local ''v'',&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt; axes; the local ''w'' and &lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes are then taken in the half-planes defined by the common local ''v'',&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt; axes and the second and third points, respectively. Right angles are formed for the local ''w'' and &lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes in these half-planes even though they may not pass precisely through the second and third points, respectively.
# If the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are not given for the second and/or third points, the local coordinate systems are placed parallel to those of the global system. This may be a convenient shortcut (see final example above), if the user is not concerned about the particular placement of the local ''w'' and &lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes.
# Any of the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups of numeric data may be replaced by the alphanumeric name of a previously defined point for which a valid &lt;tt&gt;DATA POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement has previously been given (see above examples).

==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch4_5.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 4-5:'']]
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the numeric data which simultaneously locate the two local
coordinate systems attached to the two links on either side of a &lt;tt&gt;ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; joint relative to the
absolute (global) frame of reference for the system. The pin axis is initially aligned parallel to
the global Z axis.

The &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement, taken together with the &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements for other types of joints and
the &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements, describe the relative locations of the various links of the system at
the initial (design) position.

The initial locations of the two local coordinate systems attached to the two links joined by a
&lt;tt&gt;ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement are both defined by a single &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement by specifying the global
coordinates of three points (see figure). The first point must lie at the common origins of the two
local coordinate systems. The second and third points must lie on the local positive ''u'' and
&lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes of the coordinate systems attached to the first and second links named in the &lt;tt&gt;ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt;
statement.

===Format===
 DATA ZPIN (joint name) = x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;

where ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; joint connecting the two links to which
the local coordinate systems are attached. The ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups are numeric
values for the global coordinates of the three points defining the initial locations of the two
local coordinate systems.

===Examples===
 DATA ZPIN (PIN) = -2.0,2.5,0.0; -2.0,3.5,0.0; 0.0,2.5,0.5

specifies the initial locations of the local coordinate systems attached to the two links on either
side of a &lt;tt&gt;ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; joint named PIN. The numeric data corresponds approximately to the figure. The
above example might also take any of the following forms:

 DATA ZPIN (PIN) = -2,2.5,0; -2,3.5,0; 0,2.5,.5
 DATA ZPIN (PIN) = -2,2.5, ; -2,3.5, ; ,2.5,.5
 DATA ZPIN (PIN) = PT1; PT2; 0,2.5,.5
 DATA ZPIN (PIN) = PT1

===Notes===
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# If a &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement or the two equivalent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements are not specified for each ''joint name'' defined by a &lt;tt&gt;ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'', the later statement takes precedence and earlier data are replaced.
# The dimensions for all ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data in a &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement are length units.
# Care should be taken in supplying accurate dimensional data since any errors result in improper shapes for the links and remain throughout the simulation. Slight errors cause inaccurate answers, while gross errors may cause completely unpredictable results.
# The ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data must conform to the rules for the placement of the local coordinate systems for a &lt;tt&gt;ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; joint (see &lt;tt&gt;ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement). If errors are detected, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed. Certain types of errors may not be detected until an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given; these cause the simulation to be halted and a message to be printed at that time.
# The three points for which ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are given need not be unit distances apart; the local ''u'',''v'',''w'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes are normalized by IMP to form unit vectors. The points should not be chosen coincident or too close together, however (except, perhaps, for the second and third points); larger distances achieve more accurate placement of axes.
# The angles formed by points ''2'',''1'',''3'' need not lie in a plane perpendicular to the global ''Z'' axis. IMP uses the first point to locate the common local origins and the common local ''w'',&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes; the local ''u'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes are then taken in the half-planes defined by the common local ''w'',&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes and the second and third points, respectively. Right angles are formed for the local ''u'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes in these half-planes even though they may not pass precisely through the second and third points, respectively.
# If the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are not given for the second and/or third points, the local coordinate systems are placed parallel to those of the global system. This may be a convenient shortcut (see final example above), if the user is not concerned about the particular placement of the two local ''u'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes.
# Any of the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups of numeric data may be replaced by the alphanumeric name of a previously defined point for which a valid &lt;tt&gt;DATA POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement has previously been given (see above examples).

==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch4_6.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 4-6:'']]
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the numeric data which simultaneously locate the two local
coordinate systems attached to the two links on either side of a &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; joint relative to the
absolute (global) frame of reference for the system.

The &lt;tt&gt;DATA REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statements, taken together with the &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements for other types of joints
and the &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements, describe the relative locations of the various links of the system
at the initial (design) position.

The initial locations of the two local coordinate systems attached to the two links joined by a
&lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement are both defined by a single &lt;tt&gt;DATA REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement by specifying the global
coordinates of four points (see figure). The first point must lie at the common origins of the two
local coordinate systems and the second point must lie on the common local positive ''w'',&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt;
axes. The third and fourth points must lie on the local positive ''u'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes of the
coordinate systems attached to the first and second links named in the &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement,
respectively.

===Format===
 DATA REVOLUTE (joint name) = x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;4&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;4&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;4&lt;/sub&gt;

where ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; joint connecting the two links to
which the local coordinate systems are attached. The ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups are
numeric values for the global coordinates of the four points defining the initial locations of the
two local coordinate systems.

===Examples===
 DATA REVOLUTE (PIN) = -2.0,2.5,0.0; -2.0,3.5,0.0; $
   0.0,2.5,0.5; -3.0,2.5,1.0

specifies the initial locations of the local coordinate systems attached to the two links on either
side of a &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; joint named PIN. The numeric data corresponds approximately to the figure. The
above example might also take any of the following forms:

 DATA REVOLUTE (PIN) = -2,2.5,0; -2,3.5,0; 0,2.5,.5; -3,2.5,1
 DATA REVOLUTE (PIN) = -2,2.5, ; -2,3.5, ; ,2.5,.5; -3,2.5,1
 DATA REVOLUTE (PIN) = PT1; PT2; 0,2.5,.5; -3,2.5,1
 DATA REVOLUTE (PIN) = PT1; PT2

===Notes===
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not the &lt;tt&gt;DATA REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# If a &lt;tt&gt;DATA REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement or the two equivalent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements are not specified for each ''joint name'' defined by a &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'', the later statement takes precedence and earlier data are replaced.
# The dimensions for all ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data in a &lt;tt&gt;DATA REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement are length units.
# Care should be taken in supplying accurate dimensional data since any errors result in improper shapes for the links and remain throughout the simulation. Slight errors cause inaccurate answers, while gross errors may cause completely unpredictable results.
# The ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data must conform to the rules for the placement of the local coordinate systems for a revolute joint (see &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement). If errors are detected, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed. Certain types of errors may not be detected until an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given; these cause the simulation to be halted and a message to be printed at that time.
# The four points for which ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are given need not be unit distances apart; the local ''u'',''v'',''w'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes are normalized by IMP to form unit vectors. The points should not be chosen coincident or too close together, however (except, perhaps, for the third and fourth points); larger distances achieve more accurate placement of axes.
# The angles formed by points ''2'',''1'',''3'' and by points ''2'',''1'',''4'' need not be right angles. IMP uses the first and second points to locate the common local origins and the common local ''w'',&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes; the local ''u'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes are then taken in the half-planes defined by the common local ''w'',&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes and the third and fourth points, respectively. Right angles are formed for the local ''u'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes in these half-planes even though they may not pass through the third and fourth points, respectively.
# If the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are not given for the third and/or fourth points, the coordinates of the global origin are used. In view of note 8) above, this does not produce an error unless the pin axis passes through the global origin. This may be a convenient shortcut (see final example above), if the user is not concerned about the particular placement of the local ''u'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes.
# Any of the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups of numeric data may be replaced by the alphanumeric name of a previously defined point for which a valid &lt;tt&gt;DATA POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement has previously been given (see above examples).

==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch4_7.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 4-7:'']]
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the numeric data which simultaneously locates the two local
coordinate systems attached to the two links on either side of an &lt;tt&gt;XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; joint relative to the
absolute (global) frame of reference for the system. The sliding axis is initially aligned parallel
to the global X axis.

The &lt;tt&gt;DATA XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statements, taken together with the &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements for other types of joints
and the &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements, describe the relative locations of the various links of the system
at the initial (design) position.

The initial locations of the two local coordinate systems attached to the two links joined by an
&lt;tt&gt;XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement are coincident and are both defined by a single &lt;tt&gt;DATA XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement by
specifying the global coordinates of one point (see figure). The point defines the common origins of
the two local coordinate systems. The local coordinate axes attached to the two links are set
parallel to the global axes.

===Format===
 DATA XSLIDE (joint name) = x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;

where ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; joint connecting the two links to
which the local coordinate systems are attached. The ''x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;'' are numeric values for
the global coordinates of the point defining the initial location of the origin of the two local
coordinate systems.

===Examples===
 DATA XSLIDE (SLIP) = -1.0,1.0,1.0

specifies the initial locations of the coordinate systems attached to the two links on either side
of a &lt;tt&gt;XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; joint named &lt;tt&gt;SLIP&lt;/tt&gt;. The numeric data corresponds approximately to the figure.

The above example might also take any of the following forms:

 DATA XSLIDE (SLIP) = -1,1,0
 DATA XSLIDE (SLIP) = -1,1
 DATA XSLIDE (SLIP) = PT1

===Notes===
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# If a &lt;tt&gt;DATA XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement or the two equivalent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements are not specified for each ''joint name'' defined by an &lt;tt&gt;XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'' the later statement takes precedence and earlier data are replaced.
# The dimensions for the ''x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data in a &lt;tt&gt;DATA XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement are length units.
# Care should be taken in supplying accurate dimensional data since any errors result in improper shapes for the links and remain throughout the simulation. Slight errors cause inaccurate answers, while gross errors may cause completely unpredictable results.
# The ''x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;'' group of numeric data may be replaced by the alphanumeric name of a previously defined point for which a valid &lt;tt&gt;DATA POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement has previously been given (see last example above).

==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA YSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch4_8.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 4-8:'']]

# The ''x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;'' group of numeric data may be replaced by the alphanumeric name of a previously defined point for which a valid &lt;tt&gt;DATA POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement has previously been given (see last example above).

==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch4_9.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 4-9:'']]
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the numeric data which simultaneously locates the two local
coordinate systems attached to the two links on either side of a &lt;tt&gt;ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; joint relative to the
absolute (global) frame of reference for the system. The sliding axis is aligned parallel to the
global Z axis.

The &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statements, taken together with the &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements for other types of joints
and the &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements, describe the relative locations of the various links of the system
at the initial (design) position.

The initial locations of the two local coordinate systems attached to the two links joined by a
&lt;tt&gt;ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement are coincident and are both defined by a single &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement by
specifying the global coordinates of one point (see figure). The point defines the common origins of
the two local coordinate systems. The local coordinate axes attached to the two links are set
parallel to the global axes.

===Format===
 DATA ZSLIDE (joint name) = x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;

where ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; joint connecting the two links to
which the local coordinate systems are attached. The ''x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;'' are numeric values for
the global coordinates of the point defining the initial location of the origin of the two local
coordinate systems.

===Examples===
 DATA ZSLIDE (SLIP) = -1.0,1.0,1.0

specifies the initial locations of the coordinate systems attached to the two links on either side
of a &lt;tt&gt;ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; joint named &lt;tt&gt;SLIP&lt;/tt&gt;. The numeric data corresponds approximately to the figure.

The above example might also take any of the following forms:
 DATA ZSLIDE (SLIP) = -1,1,0
 DATA ZSLIDE (SLIP) = -1,1
 DATA ZSLIDE (SLIP) = PT1

===Notes===
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# If a &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement or the two equivalent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements are not specified for each ''joint name'' defined by a &lt;tt&gt;ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'' the later statement takes precedence and earlier data are replaced.
# The dimensions for the ''x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data in a &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement are length units.
# Care should be taken in supplying accurate dimensional data since any errors result in improper shapes for the links and remain throughout the simulation. Slight errors cause inaccurate answers, while gross errors may cause completely unpredictable results.
# The ''x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;'' group of numeric data may be replaced by the alphanumeric name of a previously defined point for which a valid &lt;tt&gt;DATA POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement has been previously given (see last example above).

==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch4_10.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 4-10:'']]
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the numeric data which simultaneously locates the two local
coordinate systems attached to the two links on either side of a prismatic joint relative to the
absolute (global) frame of reference for the system.

The &lt;tt&gt;DATA PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statements, taken together with the &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements for other types of joints and
the &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements, describe the relative locations of the various links of the system at
the initial (design) position.

The initial locations of the two local coordinate systems attached to the two links joined by a
&lt;tt&gt;PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement are coincident and are both defined by a single &lt;tt&gt;DATA PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement by
specifying the global coordinates of three points (see figure). The first point defines the common
origins of the two local coordinate systems. The second point must be located on the common local
positive ''w'',&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes. The third point must lie in the half-plane defined by the common local
''w'',&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes and the common local positive ''u'',&lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes.

===Format===
 DATA PRISM (joint name) = x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;

where ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; joint connecting the two links to which
the local coordinate systems are attached. The ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups are numeric
values for the global coordinates of the three points defining the initial locations of the two
local coordinate systems.

===Examples===
 DATA PRISM (SLIP)= -1.0,1.0,0.0; -1.0,4.0,0.0; 0.0,1.0,-0.5

specifies the initial locations of the coordinate systems attached to the two links on either side
of a &lt;tt&gt;PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; joint named &lt;tt&gt;SLIP&lt;/tt&gt;. The numeric data correspond approximately to the figure.

The above example might also take any of the following forms:
 DATA PRISM (SLIP) = -1,1,0; -1,4,0; 0,1,-.5
 DATA PRISM (SLIP) = -1,1, ; -1,4, ; ,1,-.5
 DATA PRISM (SLIP) = PT1; PT2; 0,1,-.5
 DATA PRISM (SLIP) = PT1; PT2

===Notes===
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# If a &lt;tt&gt;DATA PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement or the two equivalent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements are not specified for each ''joint name'' defined by a &lt;tt&gt;PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'' the later statement takes precedence and earlier data are replaced.
# The dimensions for all ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data in a &lt;tt&gt;DATA PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement are length units.
# Care should be taken in supplying accurate dimensional data since any errors result in improper shapes for the links and remain throughout the simulation. Slight errors cause inaccurate answers, while gross errors may cause completely unpredictable results.
# The ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data must conform to the rules for the placement of the local coordinate systems for a &lt;tt&gt;PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; joint (see &lt;tt&gt;PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement). If errors are detected, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed. Certain types of errors may not be detected until an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given; these cause the simulation to be halted and a message to be printed at that time.
# The three points for which ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are given need not be unit distances apart; the local ''u'',''v'',''w'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes are normalized by IMP to form unit vectors. The points should not be chosen coincident or too close together, however; larger distances achieve more accurate placement of axes.
# The angle formed by points ''2'',''1'',''3'' need not be a right angle. IMP uses the first point to locate the common local origins extending vectors from there toward the second point; it forms the common local ''w'',&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes. The common local positive ''u'',&lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes are taken in the half-plane defined by the common local ''w'',&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes and the third point; a right angle is then formed for the common local ''u'',&lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes in the half-plane even though they may not pass through the third point.
# If the ''x&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are not given for the third point, the coordinates of the global origin are used. In view of note 8) above, this does not produce an error unless the common local ''w'',&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes pass through the global origin. This may be a convenient shortcut (see final example above) if the user is not concerned about the particular placement of the local ''u'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes.
# Any of the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups of numeric data may be replaced by the alphanumeric name of a previously defined point for which a valid &lt;tt&gt;DATA POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement has previously been given (see last example above).

==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the gear ratio and the center to
center distance for a &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; joint.

===Format===
 DATA GEAR (joint name) = ratio, distance

where ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; joint, ''ratio'' is the numeric value of
the gear ratio for the joint, and ''distance'' is the numeric value of the center to center distance
(the sum of the pitch radii) for the two mating &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; sectors.

===Example===
 DATA GEAR (SPUR) = 2.625, 6.25

specifies that the gear ratio of a spur gear joint named &lt;tt&gt;SPUR&lt;/tt&gt; is 84:32 = 2.625, and that the sum
of the pitch radii of the mating gear sectors is 4.526 + 1.724 = 6.25 length units.

===Notes===
# There must be a &lt;tt&gt;DATA GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; statement for each joint defined by a &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If these are not specified before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the simulation is halted and a message is printed.
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# Unlike &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements describing certain other types of joints (for example, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement), the &lt;tt&gt;DATA GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; statement does not specify the locations of the two local coordinate systems for the &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; joint; two &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements must be defined for each ''joint name'' defined by a &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If these do not appear before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'', the later statement takes precedence; earlier data are replaced and a message is printed.
# The value of ''ratio'' is dimensionless; the value of ''distance'' has units of length.
# The value of ''ratio'' is the ratio of the number of teeth (or the pitch diameter) of the first gear named in the &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; statement to the number of teeth (or pitch diameter) of the second gear named. A positive value of ''ratio'' indicates that both are external gears, while a negative ''ratio'' indicates an internal-external gear combination.
# A value of zero may not be used for ''ratio'' to represent a gear-rack combination. A zero value for ''ratio'' causes the &lt;tt&gt;DATA GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# The center to center ''distance'' is optional; it need not be specified by the user. If it is not specified before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, it will be calculated from data for the local coordinate systems on either side of the joint at that time.
# If the center to center ''distance'' is given, it should be consistent with the placement of the two local coordinate systems on either side of the gear joint. If not consistent at the time an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the kinematic shapes of all links will be found first from the locations of the local coordinate systems; the two gear centers will then be set to the specified distance; any discrepancies will be compensated for by movements within the joints of the system when assembly is attempted at the design (initial) position.

==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the gear ratio and the size of the two bevel gears defined by a
previous &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement.

===Format===
 DATA BEVEL (joint name) = ratio, radius

where each ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; joint, ''ratio'' is the numeric
value of the gear ratio for the joint, and ''radius'' is the pitch circle radius of the second link
named in the &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement.

===Example===
 DATA BEVEL (BVL) = 2.625, 2.0

specifies that the gear ratio of a &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; joint named &lt;tt&gt;BVL&lt;/tt&gt; is 84/32 = 2.625 and that the back-face
pitch circle radii of the two bevel gears are 5.25 and 2.0 length units, respectively.

===Notes===
# There must be a &lt;tt&gt;DATA BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement for each joint defined by a &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If these are not specified before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the simulation is halted and a message is printed.
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# Unlike &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements describing certain other types of joints (for example, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement), the &lt;tt&gt;DATA BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement does not specify the locations of the two local coordinate systems for the &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; joint; two &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements must be defined for each &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; joint. If these do not appear before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'', the later statement takes precedence; earlier data are replaced and a message is printed.
# The value of ''ratio'' is dimensionless; the value of ''radius'' has units of length.
# The value of ''ratio'' is the ratio of the number of teeth of the first bevel gear named in the &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement to the number of teeth of the second.
# The value of ''ratio'' must be a positive number. A zero or negative value for ''ratio'' causes the &lt;tt&gt;DATA BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# The angle between the two intersecting shafts of a &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; joint is always 90  . The two local coordinate systems defined by the two &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements are assumed to be at consistent distances from the intersection of the two shafts, that is, the u,v and u,v planes are both chosen to go through the point of contact of the respective pitch circles (see figure with &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement). The ''radius'' specified is the pitch circle radius of the second gear named, measured in the u,v plane. It should equal the distance from the shaft intersection to the u,v plane.


==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA RACK&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA RACK&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the pinion radius for a &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; joint.

===Format===
 DATA RACK (joint name) = radius

where each ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; joint and ''radius'' is the pitch
circle radius of the second link named in the &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; statement.

===Example===
 DATA RACK (MESH) = 2.5
specifies that the pitch circle radius of the pinion in a &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; joint named &lt;tt&gt;MESH&lt;/tt&gt; is 2.5 length
units.

===Notes===
# There must be a &lt;tt&gt;DATA RACK&lt;/tt&gt; statement for each joint defined by a &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If these are not specified before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the simulation is halted and a message is printed.
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA RACK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# Unlike &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements describing certain other types of joints (for example, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement), the &lt;tt&gt;DATA RACK&lt;/tt&gt; statement does not specify the locations of the two local coordinate systems for the &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; joint; two &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; state- ments must also be defined for each &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; joint. If these do not appear before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local ''u'',''v'',''w'' or &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the x,y,z link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA RACK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'', the later statement takes precedence; earlier data are replaced and a message is printed.
# The value of ''radius'' has units of length. It should be equal to the perpendicular distance from the local &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; origin to the local u axis (see figure with the &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# The value of ''radius'' may not be zero. If zero is specified for ''radius'', the &lt;tt&gt;DATA RACK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.


==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the lead of a screw joint.

===Format===
 DATA SCREW (joint name) = value

where ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; joint and ''value'' is the numeric
value of the lead of the &lt;tt&gt;SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; joint thread.

===Example===
 DATA SCREW (THRD) = -0.750

specifies the lead of a &lt;tt&gt;SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; joint named &lt;tt&gt;THRD&lt;/tt&gt; as 0.750 length units per revolution with a
left-hand thread.

===Notes===
# There must be a &lt;tt&gt;DATA SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; statement for each joint defined by a &lt;tt&gt;SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If these are not specified before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the simulation is halted and a message is printed.
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# Unlike &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements describing certain other types of joints (for example, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement), the &lt;tt&gt;DATA SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; statement does not specify the locations of the two local coordinate systems for the &lt;tt&gt;SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; joint; two &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements must also be specified for each ''joint name'' defined by a &lt;tt&gt;SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If these do not appear before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'', the later statement takes precedence; earlier data are replaced and a message is printed.
# The dimensions of ''value'' are length units of advance of the screw per revolution. A right-hand thread has a positive ''value'' and a left-hand thread has a negative ''value''.
# The ''value'' of the lead may not be zero. A &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement should be used instead of a &lt;tt&gt;SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; for this case. If zero is specified for ''value'', the &lt;tt&gt;DATA SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.


==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA CAM&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA CAM&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the shape of the pitch curve for a &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; joint.

===Format===
 DATA CAM (joint name) = value name

where ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; joint and ''value name'' is the
alphanumeric name of a previously defined &lt;tt&gt;VALUE&lt;/tt&gt; expression set equal to a &lt;tt&gt;TABLE&lt;/tt&gt; function giving
data for the pitch curve for the &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; joint.

===Example===
 VALUE (R) = TABLE (PHI): datafile.dat
 DATA CAM (CURV) = R

specifies that the pitch curve radius of a &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; joint named &lt;tt&gt;CURV&lt;/tt&gt; is specified by a &lt;tt&gt;VALUE&lt;/tt&gt;
expression named R which refers to a &lt;tt&gt;TABLE&lt;/tt&gt; function referencing a file named datafile.dat''.

===Notes===
# There must be a &lt;tt&gt;DATA CAM&lt;/tt&gt; statement for each joint defined by a &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If these are not specified before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the simulation is halted and a message is printed.
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA CAM&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# Unlike &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements describing certain other types of joints (for example, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement), the &lt;tt&gt;DATA CAM&lt;/tt&gt; statement does not specify the locations of the two local coordinate systems for the &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; joint; two &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; state- ments must also be defined for each &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; joint. If these do not appear before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA CAM&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'', the later statement takes precedence; earlier data are replaced and a message is printed.
# The ''value name'' must refer to a previously defined &lt;tt&gt;VALUE&lt;/tt&gt; expression consisting solely of a &lt;tt&gt;TABLE&lt;/tt&gt; function; other kinds of &lt;tt&gt;VALUE&lt;/tt&gt; expression cannot be used. If this is not satisfied the &lt;tt&gt;DATA CAM&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# The argument of the &lt;tt&gt;TABLE&lt;/tt&gt; function is arbitrary and is not used. During the simulation, the &lt;tt&gt;TABLE&lt;/tt&gt; function is evaluated as if the independent variable is the first joint variable of the &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; joint, an angle (in radians). Thus the data file referred to by the &lt;tt&gt;TABLE&lt;/tt&gt; function should specify tabular data (see section 2-7.29) for the radius of the pitch curve as a function of angle (in radians) measured relative to the u,v coordinate system (see figure with the &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; statement) of the first link named in the &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; statement. The tabular data should specify radii for equally spaced angular increments for a full rotation (2 PI = 6.28318 radians).
# The dimensions of the tabular data for the pitch curve radius are in length units.


==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the shape of the slot for a &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; joint.

===Format===
 DATA SLOT (joint name) = value name

where ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; joint and ''value name'' is the
alphanumeric name of a previously defined &lt;tt&gt;VALUE&lt;/tt&gt; expression set equal to a &lt;tt&gt;TABLE&lt;/tt&gt; function giving
data for the centerline curve of the slot.

===Example===
 VALUE (Y) = TABLE&lt;tt&gt; (&lt;/tt&gt;PHI`): datafile.dat
 DATA SLOT (CURV) = V

specifies that the profiled shape of the centerline curve of a &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; joint named &lt;tt&gt;CURV&lt;/tt&gt; is
specified by a file named datafile.dat'' and a &lt;tt&gt;VALUE&lt;/tt&gt; expression named V accessing that file via a
&lt;tt&gt;TABLE&lt;/tt&gt; function.

===Notes===
# There must be a &lt;tt&gt;DATA SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; statement for each joint defined by  a &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If these are not specified before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the simulation is halted and a message is printed.
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# Unlike &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements describing certain other types of joints (for example, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement), the &lt;tt&gt;DATA SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; statement does not specify the locations of the two local coordinate systems for the &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; joint; two &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements must also be defined for each &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; joint. If these do not appear before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'', the later statement takes precedence; earlier data are replaced and a message is printed.
# The ''value name'' must refer to a previously defined &lt;tt&gt;VALUE&lt;/tt&gt; expression consisting solely of a &lt;tt&gt;TABLE&lt;/tt&gt; function; other kinds of &lt;tt&gt;VALUE&lt;/tt&gt; expression cannot be used. If this is not satisfied the &lt;tt&gt;DATA SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# The argument of the &lt;tt&gt;TABLE&lt;/tt&gt; function is arbitrary and is not used. During the simulation, the &lt;tt&gt;TABLE&lt;/tt&gt; function is evaluated as if the independent variable is the first joint variable of the &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; joint, a distance along the u axis (see figure for the &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; joint). Thus the datafile referred to by the &lt;tt&gt;TABLE&lt;/tt&gt; function should specify tabular data (see section 2-7.29) for the v distances for the profiled slot centerline as a function of u relative to the u,v coordinate system of the first link named in the &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; statement. The tabular data should specify v(u) values for equally spaced increment of u over the full length of the slot.
# The dimensions for v in the tabular data for the slot profile are length units.


==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch4_11.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 4-11:'']]
The &lt;tt&gt;DATA CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement specifies the numeric data which simultaneously locates the two local coordinate systems attachedto the two links on either side of a &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; joint relative tothe absolute (global) frame of reference for the system.

The &lt;tt&gt;DATA CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statements, taken together with the &lt;tt&gt;DATA&lt;/tt&gt; statements for other types of joints and the &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements,describe the relative locations of the various links of the systemat the initial (design) position.

The initial locations of the two local coordinate systems attached to the two links joined by a &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement are coincident and are both defined by a single &lt;tt&gt;DATA CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement by specifying the global coordinates of three points (see figure). The first point must lie at the common origin of the two localcoordinate systems. The second point must be located on the common local positive ''w'',&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes. The third point must lie in the half-plane defined by the common local ''w'',&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes and the common local positive ''u'',&lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes.

===Format===
 DATA CYLINDER (joint name) = x&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;1&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;; x&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,y&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;,z&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt;

where ''joint name'' is the alphanumeric name of the &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; joint connecting the two links to
which the local coordinate systems are attached. The ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups are
numeric values for the global coordinates of the three points defining the initial locations of
the two local ''u'',''v'',''w'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; coordinate systems.

===Examples===
 DATA CYLINDER(CYL)=-1.0,1.0,0.0;-1.0,4.0,0.0;0.0,1.0,-0.5

specifies the initial locations of the two coincident ''u'',''v'',''w'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt;
coordinate systems attached to the two links on either side of a &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; joint named CYL. The
numeric data corresponds approximately to the figure.

The above example might also take any of the following forms:
 DATA CYLINDER (CYL) = -1,1,0; -1,4,0; 0,1,-.5
 DATA CYLINDER (CYL) = -1,1, ; -1,4, ; ,1,-.5
 DATA CYLINDER (CYL) = PT1; PT2; 0,1,-.5
 DATA CYLINDER (CYL) = PT1; PT2

===Notes===
# The ''joint name'' specified must have been defined by a previous &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# If a &lt;tt&gt;DATA CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement or the two equivalent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements are not specified for each ''joint name'' defined by a &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, the local coordinate system(s) with missing data is (are) initially placed coincident with the link frame of reference.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;DATA CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given for the same ''joint name'', the later statement takes precedence and earlier data are replaced.
# The dimensions for all ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data in a &lt;tt&gt;DATA CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement are length units.
# Care should be taken in supplying accurate dimensional data since any errors result in improper shapes for the links and remain throughout the simulation. Slight errors cause inaccurate answers, while gross errors may cause completely unpredictable results.
# The ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data must conform to the rules for the placement of the local coordinate systems for a &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; joint (see &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement). If errors are detected, the &lt;tt&gt;DATA CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed. Certain types of errors may not be detected until an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given; these cause the simulation to be halted and a message to be printed at that time.
# The three points for which ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are given need not be unit distances apart; the local ''u'',''v'',''w'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;v&lt;/i&gt;,&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes are normalized by IMP to form unit vectors. The points should not be chosen coincident or too close together, however; larger distances achieve more accurate placement of axes.
# The angle formed by points ''2'',''1'',''3'' need not be a right angle. IMP uses the first point to locate the two coincident local origins; extending a vector toward the second point, it then forms the common local ''w'' and &lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes. The common local positive ''u'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes are then taken in the half-plane defined by the common local ''w'' and &lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes and the third point; a right angle is formed for the common local ''u'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes in this half-plane even though they may not exactly pass through the third point.
# If the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' numeric data are not given for the third point, the coordinates of the global origin are used. In view of note 8) above, this does not produce an error unless the common local ''w'',&lt;i&gt;w&lt;/i&gt; axes pass through the global origin. This may be a convenient shortcut (see final example above) if the user is not concerned about the particular placement of the local ''u'' and &lt;i&gt;u&lt;/i&gt; axes.
# Any of the ''x&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''y&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'',''z&lt;sub&gt;i&lt;/sub&gt;'' groups of numeric data may be replaced by the alphanumeric name of a previously defined point for which a valid &lt;tt&gt;DATA POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement has previously been given (see above examples).

==The &lt;tt&gt;DATA UJOINT&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch4_12.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 4-12:'']]
